2.1 Skinny Motion
This is the first of three outlines of some basic physics ideas so that I can refer to them in other posts. If you‚Äôd like more, including history and examples, then visit full textbook for a textbook-level presentation. If you only need the basic simple equations, they‚Äôre here. If you‚Äôd like some explanation, that‚Äôs next!
Units. Sorry. In QS&BB we won‚Äôt care about English versus metric units but for this motion review we‚Äôll sometimes have to convert. I‚Äôll do it for you but you can check me at places like unitjuggler‚Ä¶or often just Google.

title: 2¬† Motion, Speed, and Acceleration
text:
2.3 average quantities

2.3.1 speed
The average speed that an object has after going a distance of \(x_f\) after starting at position \(x_0\) in a time \(\Delta t\) is: \[
\begin{equation}
<v> = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x_f-x_0}{t_f - t_0}
\end{equation}
\] so: ### average distance traveled
\[
x =x_0 +<v>\times(t-t_0)
\]
often abstracted to: \[
x=vt
\]

2.4.1 definition of acceleration
Not restricted to constant acceleration: \[
a = \frac{v-v_0}{t-t_0}
\]

\[
v = v_0 +at
\]

\[
x = x_0 + v_0t + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2
\] ### Velocity for constant acceleration after given distance

v^2   = v_0^2 + 2ax
\]

Down ‚Üì presumed to be in the positive direction (same direction as the motion and the force of gravity) \[
y = y_0 + v_0t + \dfrac{1}{2} gt^2
\] ## Different way

3 Gentle explanations of Velocity and Acceleration

3.1 Getting From Here to There: At Constant Speed
Whether it‚Äôs runners on a track, the cosmic rays piercing us all the time, orbiting planets, electrons in a wire, electromagnetic waves, quark wavefunctions inside a proton, electrons and holes in a semiconductor, or the stretching of spacetime itself. Everything is about ‚Äúmotion.‚Äù Motion is both the easiest and the hardest concept in physics and so much of what comes for us will constantly stretch at ideas about what motion is and how we can describe it. So we need to start at the beginning. Because:

motion: it‚Äôs everywhere Almost everything in physics boils down to: motion. (Even boiling.)

But at its most basic, our physics will be all about how to get from here to  there and from  then to  now, and to be able to explain how that happened and predict what will come next.








Figure¬†3.1: Everywhere you look: motion.





Characterizing motion is simple in principle! You need two things:



screenshot_3644


And for everyday motion, that seems reasonable and you already know a lot about that.
Suppose you‚Äôre on a trip and you timed yourself between the two mile markers.



screenshot_3645


What was your speed? I know you know this and your brain would quickly calculate:

I went 350 ‚Äì 50 = 300 miies
it took me 6 hours
so my speed was 300/6 = 50 ‚Äúmiles per hour,‚Äù mph

So: \[v=50\] mph
Now, what if we stop and then start up after a break? How do we refer to the speed then?



screenshot_3646




3.2 Average speed
So as time marches on, part of it we‚Äôd be moving and part of it we‚Äôd be stationary. But notice that the times are no different and the distances are no different. Now your brain would be doing an average speed calculation with exactly the same beginning and ending times and distances. You‚Äôd now say that:
\[<v> = 50\] mph
This bracketing notation means ‚Äúaverage‚Äù or ‚Äúmean‚Äù‚Ä¶the average speed only depends on the beginning and ending points. Since the same number of hours elapsed, as before without the stop, we must have gone faster than the average before the stop and/or faster after the stop. Average speeds are not that unfamiliar, but that‚Äôs because you don‚Äôt probably think of it that way. But you‚Äôve all asked yourselves the question, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got to go 100 miles and I think I can travel at 70 mph, so I‚Äùll be home in about one and a half hours.‚Äù
So you‚Äôve known for a long time that
\(\text{speed} = \dfrac{\text{distance traveled}}{\text{time taken}}\)
is the rate at which distance changes with time.

3.2.1 Speed in Modern Terms
Let‚Äôs make this more compact by inserting customary symbols to get rid of the English words. Here are some grammar rules in QS&BB:

We‚Äôll limit ourselves almost exclusively to motion in one dimension in space.
We‚Äôll use the symbol \(v\) for speed (because customarily, we‚Äôll speak of ‚Äúvelocity‚Äù‚Ä¶more about this below).
\(<A>\) is the average of the quantity \(A\)
We‚Äôll use the symbol \(x\) for distance in one dimension, regardless of which direction it points.
We‚Äôll use the symbol \(t\) for time and almost always presume that we set our clocks so that the beginning time of any interval is \(t_0=0\).
Oh, and we‚Äôll use the subscript \(\text{ }_{0}\) to indicate the beginning of some time or location interval‚Äî‚Äù \(t_0\)‚Äù or ‚Äù \(x_0\) ‚Äù‚Äîin a sequence of events.
We‚Äôll use the Greek symbol Delta, \(\Delta\) to mean ‚Äúchange of‚Äù‚Ä¶this will come up a lot.

With this, then we can ‚Äúsolve‚Äù this simple problem:
\[
\begin{align}
v &= \text{speed}=\dfrac{\text{distance traveled}}{\text{time taken}} \nonumber \\
v &=\dfrac{x-x_0}{t-t_0} \label{speeddef}\\
&= \dfrac{350-50}{6}=50  \text{mph} \nonumber
\end{align}
\]
where ‚Äú\(v\)‚Äù is the velocity and it‚Äôs defined by the middle equation in equation \(\eqref{speeddef}\).



3.3 Dimensional Analysis
This might be superfluous for most of your interests, but sometimes it‚Äôs usefult to keep track of the dimensions of quantities. It can check an answer after a calculation ‚Äì¬†if the dimension of a result shoudl be mph but it comes out to be ‚Äúfeet‚Äù then you made a mistake somewhere. But it‚Äôs also useful to keep track of changing from one set of units to another, like miles per hour to meters per second.
The usual way of keeping track of the dimensions is a different kind of bracket: \([A]\) would refer to the ‚Äúdimension of \(A\)‚Äù.
So if our distance units were feet and our time units were hours, then we would say that the dimensions of velocity could be determined to be:
\[\dfrac{[\text{distance}]}{[\text{time}]}=\dfrac{\text{feet}}{\text{hours}} = [v] = \text{feet per hour}\]


3.4 Spacespace and Spacetime Diagrams
There are multiple ways to represent motion‚Ä¶ an equation like ?eq-eq1 is a model. But graphical representation is also very useful. Here are two:

3.4.1 spacespace diagram, stationary
Let‚Äôs imagine a pool table. Here it is with a set of x-y axes. Notice that I‚Äôve placed a ball at the intial coordinates (x0, y0):

#| echo: false
knitr::include_graphics("screenshot_3649.png")







Figure¬†3.2: Our platform for describing motion. A ball on a pool table‚Ä¶sitting there minding its own business.





Wait a while‚Ä¶here it still is:



screenshot_3649


Let‚Äôs plot it on an x-y axis set.



screenshot_3657


!](screenshot_3656.png)
I call this diagram a spacespace diagram since both axes are space coordinates. It‚Äôs how you think about things normally. As time progresses, our ball doesn‚Äôt move on the table, so the x and y coordinates of the ball at any time are the same.


3.4.2 spacetime diagram, stationary
Now supposed I plot the ball‚Äôs trajectory (yes, ‚Äútrajectory‚Äù) as a function of space and time.



screenshot_3658


Now you see ‚Äúmovement‚Äù‚Ä¶the stationary ball is moving in time. This picture is an example of a spacetime diagram. Not very interesting.


3.4.3 spacespace diagram, moving!
Just sitting still isn‚Äôt interesting, so let‚Äôs roll the ball across the pool table:



screenshot_3665


While the ball moves in space, it‚Äôs also moving in time but the time coordinate is implied or hidden. The clocks show what it might be if one were to use a stopwatch to monitor its motion for 4 points along the trajectory.
Since the ball moves only horizontally, \(y_0\) doesn‚Äôt change and so I can represent the motion in a space (\(x\)) and time (\(t\)) way and here is the spacetime diagram for this simple situation
Notice that the trajectory in spacetime is a straight line and its slope? The velocity, which is a continuous curve in this diagram, and the dashed line shows it.


3.4.4 Graphing motion
This is a model of motion, which for physicists is always a curve in some coordinate system. Here the slope is \[
\begin{align}
v &=\dfrac{x-x_0}{t-t_0} \nonumber \\
v &= \dfrac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} \nonumber
\end{align}
\] We can easily imagine that the motion might not be smooth (like the stopping and starting on the road above) and so the concept of the average is always in play:



screenshot_3667


The more precisely we sample the motion, the more precisely we converge on an instantaneous speed, which you‚Äôre familiar with while driving with a speedometer in front of you. You think it‚Äôs telling you exaclty what your speed is, but it is actually digitally sampling the rotation of your tires, but very finely.
In physics:

‚Äúkinematics‚Äù is the subject of motion
‚Äúdynamics‚Äù is the subject of forces‚Ä¶which cause the motion

Galileo introduced the idea of kinematics‚Ä¶he characterized motion without regard to what made the motion happen. Isaac Newton did the first legitimate analysis ‚Äì model¬†‚Äì of dynamics. He explained how to characterize forces and the motions that result. That‚Äôs the subject of the next chapter.


3.4.5 Acceleration
The rolling ball‚Äôs motion in spacetime had the same slope between any two time intervals ‚Äì a straight line. So the velocity never changes.
But of course for motion to get started one has begin from rest and get going, so the velocity has to increase in time. That‚Äôs what acceleration is.

Velocity is the rate at which distance changes in time.
Acceleration is the rate at which velocity changes in time.

Here are the two models of motion:
\[
\begin{align}
v &=\dfrac{x-x_0}{t-t_0} \text{  model of velocity} \\
v &= \dfrac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} \text{ and } \nonumber \\
a &=\dfrac{v-v_0}{t-t_0}  \text{  model of acceleration} \nonumber \\
a &= \dfrac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \nonumber
\end{align}
\]
So if the speed is uniform, like the ball above, then the acceleration is zero (since \(\Delta v = 0\)).
If the speed changes in time, then we have accelerated motion since \(\Delta v \ne 0\).
Dimensions of acceleration are a little unfamiliar but we can work them out:



screenshot_3668


Of course the simplest acceleration is a constant one‚Ä¶that during any time interval, the speed increases and the rate at which the speed increases is constant. 
But sometimes you put on the brakes, and you know that you slow down because you can feel it and the speedometer is telling you that. So in increasing time intervals, the rate at which the speed changes is negative. 
In the diagram, \(\Delta v < 0\). This is a negative acceleration and is called decceleration.
I‚Äôve concentrated on acceleration and deceleration which are constant‚Ä¶the speed changes at a uniform rate, up or down. But that‚Äôs not the only kind. Think about a sprinter. Just after the starting gun, a runner‚Äôs speed out of the blocks is high and remains high for the first few steps. As the runner starts to become a little more vertical, air resistance becomes a factor and while the runner goes faster, she does so at a lower rate of speed increase. That‚Äôs a non-constant acceleration.

Now you can design a sports video game. All you have to do is measure an athlete‚Äôs personal acceleration parameters and code them. I found this years ago for Madden NFL11 of a particular running back:



3.5 Gravity
Famously, Galileo Galilei determined that any object near the earth would fall at a constant acceleration. How he determined this was clever and you can read the story at Galileo. What he found was that the speed of a falling object would increase linearly with the time of it‚Äôs fall. A competing idea from other natural philosophers including Leonardo DaVinci, proposed that the speed would increase linearly with distance, not time.
What Galileo knew from medieval considerations was that this linearity with time for \(v\) meant that distance had to increase quadratically with time.
So, a model of Galileo‚Äôs qualitative conclusion is: \[
\begin{align}
v(t) &\propto t \nonumber \\
x(t) &\propto t^2 \nonumber
\end{align}
\] The symbol \(\propto\) means ‚Äúproportional to‚Äù and when we find a relationship like that, we can turn it into an equation by inserting some constant of proportionality. For falling bodies near the earth, the symbol for that constant is called ‚Äú\(g\)‚Äù or ‚Äúlittle g.‚Äù Now we can fully-form the model as: \[
\begin{align}
v(t) &= gt \nonumber \\
x(t) &= 1/2gt^2 \nonumber
\end{align}
\] There are simplicity reasons for the 1/2‚Ä¶if we‚Äôd absorbed that into \(g\) then the first equation would have had to change. The value of \(g\) comes from experiment and is about \[
\begin{equation}
g = 9.8 \text{ m/s$^2$} = 32 \text{ ft/s$^2$}.  \nonumber \\
\end{equation}
\] While this is a story that started with gravity, it‚Äôs nonetheless a completely general description of any accelerated motion (your car) if that acceleration is constant. In general, then, we‚Äôd use the symbol \(a\) and treat falling as a special case of constantly accelerated motion in which case \(a=g\).
While we defined speed in terms of distance, we can rewrite ?eq-eq1
\[
\begin{align}
\text{For constant speed,}&\text{ no acceleration} \\
v &=\dfrac{x-x_0}{t-t_0} \nonumber \\
x-x_0 &=v(t-t_0) \nonumber \text{ let's take our initial time be 0} \\
x &= x_0 + vt
\end{align}
\]
And for constant acceleration, we can find a general relationship for distance as well with a simple calculation.






Warning



‚ö†Ô∏è A bit of algebra is required to derive the complete quartet of equations for motion with a constant acceleration. I do that for you in equations of motion




3.6 Complete model for motion
So collectively, here are our definitions for motion:
\[
\begin{align}
\text{Constant speed,}&\text{ no acceleration} \nonumber \\
x &= x_0 + vt \nonumber \\
v &= \text{ constant} \nonumber \\
a &= 0 \nonumber \\
\text{Constant}&\text{ acceleration}& \nonumber \\
a &=\dfrac{v-v_0}{t-t_0} \nonumber \\
a &= \dfrac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \nonumber \\
\end{align}
\]
And here are the complete set of equations for one-dimentional constant acceleration. Each relation relates two of the three variables: \(x, t, v\).
\[
\begin{align}
& \text{1. } \; x = \langle v \rangle t \label{avev} \\
& \text{2.  } \; v   = v_0 + at \label{vat} \\
& \text{3. }  \; x   = x_0+v_0 t + \frac{1}{2} at^2 \label{xat}  \\
& \text{4. }\; v^2   = v_0^2 + 2ax \label{vax}
\end{align}
\]
Notice two things. If the motion is at a constant velocity, then setting \(a=0\) recovers that special case. And notice that \(\eqref{vax}\) does not have time as a variable and that will turn out to be interesting when we talk about energy.



3.7 Projectiles
When you throw a ball from centerfield to home plate, the ball executes what looks like a parabollic trajectory. The ball goes forward while it probably rises for a while and then drops toward the ground. That‚Äôs two-dimensional motion and Galileo had the insipiration to figure out what was going on and how to do experiments to confirm his hypothesis that the up-and-down would follow the shape of a parabola.
His insight was that when motion is imparted to an object and the source of the motion is taken away (you throw the ball and it leaves your hand and is then in its own), that something stays with the ball. He called it ‚Äúimpeto‚Äù and we call it ‚Äúmomentum.‚Äù The ball acquires momentum.
And he realized that whatever impeto the ball acquires in the horizontal direction is preserved, but the moment the ball leaves your hand, it starts to head toward the Earth. In modern words, we‚Äôd say that once released, the ball has a horizontal momentum that stays constant and a vertical momentum that changes and points down. The two motions are in some sense overlaid or shared by the ball.

# #| out.width: ‚Äú700px‚Äù  
# #| column: screen
#| echo: false
knitr::include_graphics("screenshot_3677.png")







Figure¬†3.3: Throwing a ball. The vertical axis is the height above the ground and the horizontal axis is the range. The curve shows the trajectory of a thrown ball in the absence of any air resistance ‚Äì a perfect parabola. The intitial velocity is shown as the arrow at location 1. At each of the five points the overall velocity is broken into horizontal and vertical components.





In the figure you can see that the original velocity \(v_1\) points up and foward and I‚Äôve broken up this arrow (a vector) into it‚Äôs horizontal component which you can see at 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 is the same length. It‚Äôs ‚Äúimpeto‚Äù is constant. The vertical component changes at each point ‚Äì disappearing at the top ‚Äì¬†and then increasing down as the ball heads to Earth. Gravity wins.
For QS&BB we‚Äôll not need two dimensional kinematics.










A sprinter‚Äôs changing acceleration. Notice that the slope changes as time inncreases

Galileo introduced the idea of kinematics‚Ä¶he characterized motion without regard to what made the motion happen. Isaac Newton did the first legitimate analysis ‚Äì model¬†‚Äì of dynamics. He explained how to characterize forces and the motions that result. That‚Äôs the subject of the next chapter.


3.4.5 Acceleration
The rolling ball‚Äôs motion in spacetime had the same slope between any two time intervals ‚Äì a straight line. So the velocity never changes.
But of course for motion to get started one has begin from rest and get going, so the velocity has to increase in time. That‚Äôs what acceleration is.

Velocity is the rate at which distance changes in time.
Acceleration is the rate at which velocity changes in time.

Here are the two models of motion:
\[
\begin{align}
v &=\dfrac{x-x_0}{t-t_0} \text{  model of velocity} \\
v &= \dfrac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} \text{ and } \nonumber \\
a &=\dfrac{v-v_0}{t-t_0}  \text{  model of acceleration} \nonumber \\
a &= \dfrac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \nonumber
\end{align}
\]
So if the speed is uniform, like the ball above, then the acceleration is zero (since \(\Delta v = 0\)).
If the speed changes in time, then we have accelerated motion since \(\Delta v \ne 0\).
Dimensions of acceleration are a little unfamiliar but we can work them out:



screenshot_3668


Of course the simplest acceleration is a constant one‚Ä¶that during any time interval, the speed increases and the rate at which the speed increases is constant. 
But sometimes you put on the brakes, and you know that you slow down because you can feel it and the speedometer is telling you that. So in increasing time intervals, the rate at which the speed changes is negative. 
In the diagram, \(\Delta v < 0\). This is a negative acceleration and is called decceleration.
I‚Äôve concentrated on acceleration and deceleration which are constant‚Ä¶the speed changes at a uniform rate, up or down. But that‚Äôs not the only kind. Think about a sprinter. Just after the starting gun, a runner‚Äôs speed out of the blocks is high and remains high for the first few steps. As the runner starts to become a little more vertical, air resistance becomes a factor and while the runner goes faster, she does so at a lower rate of speed increase. That‚Äôs a non-constant acceleration.

Now you can design a sports video game. All you have to do is measure an athlete‚Äôs personal acceleration parameters and code them. I found this years ago for Madden NFL11 of a particular running back:

title: 2¬† Motion, Speed, and Acceleration
text:
3.5 Gravity
Famously, Galileo Galilei determined that any object near the earth would fall at a constant acceleration. How he determined this was clever and you can read the story at Galileo. What he found was that the speed of a falling object would increase linearly with the time of it‚Äôs fall. A competing idea from other natural philosophers including Leonardo DaVinci, proposed that the speed would increase linearly with distance, not time.
What Galileo knew from medieval considerations was that this linearity with time for \(v\) meant that distance had to increase quadratically with time.
So, a model of Galileo‚Äôs qualitative conclusion is: \[
\begin{align}
v(t) &\propto t \nonumber \\
x(t) &\propto t^2 \nonumber
\end{align}
\] The symbol \(\propto\) means ‚Äúproportional to‚Äù and when we find a relationship like that, we can turn it into an equation by inserting some constant of proportionality. For falling bodies near the earth, the symbol for that constant is called ‚Äú\(g\)‚Äù or ‚Äúlittle g.‚Äù Now we can fully-form the model as: \[
\begin{align}
v(t) &= gt \nonumber \\
x(t) &= 1/2gt^2 \nonumber
\end{align}
\] There are simplicity reasons for the 1/2‚Ä¶if we‚Äôd absorbed that into \(g\) then the first equation would have had to change. The value of \(g\) comes from experiment and is about \[
\begin{equation}
g = 9.8 \text{ m/s$^2$} = 32 \text{ ft/s$^2$}.  \nonumber \\
\end{equation}
\] While this is a story that started with gravity, it‚Äôs nonetheless a completely general description of any accelerated motion (your car) if that acceleration is constant. In general, then, we‚Äôd use the symbol \(a\) and treat falling as a special case of constantly accelerated motion in which case \(a=g\).
While we defined speed in terms of distance, we can rewrite ?eq-eq1
\[
\begin{align}
\text{For constant speed,}&\text{ no acceleration} \\
v &=\dfrac{x-x_0}{t-t_0} \nonumber \\
x-x_0 &=v(t-t_0) \nonumber \text{ let's take our initial time be 0} \\
x &= x_0 + vt
\end{align}
\]
And for constant acceleration, we can find a general relationship for distance as well with a simple calculation.






Warning



‚ö†Ô∏è A bit of algebra is required to derive the complete quartet of equations for motion with a constant acceleration. I do that for you in equations of motion

title: 2¬† Motion, Speed, and Acceleration
text:
3.6 Complete model for motion
So collectively, here are our definitions for motion:
\[
\begin{align}
\text{Constant speed,}&\text{ no acceleration} \nonumber \\
x &= x_0 + vt \nonumber \\
v &= \text{ constant} \nonumber \\
a &= 0 \nonumber \\
\text{Constant}&\text{ acceleration}& \nonumber \\
a &=\dfrac{v-v_0}{t-t_0} \nonumber \\
a &= \dfrac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \nonumber \\
\end{align}
\]
And here are the complete set of equations for one-dimentional constant acceleration. Each relation relates two of the three variables: \(x, t, v\).
\[
\begin{align}
& \text{1. } \; x = \langle v \rangle t \label{avev} \\
& \text{2.  } \; v   = v_0 + at \label{vat} \\
& \text{3. }  \; x   = x_0+v_0 t + \frac{1}{2} at^2 \label{xat}  \\
& \text{4. }\; v^2   = v_0^2 + 2ax \label{vax}
\end{align}
\]
Notice two things. If the motion is at a constant velocity, then setting \(a=0\) recovers that special case. And notice that \(\eqref{vax}\) does not have time as a variable and that will turn out to be interesting when we talk about energy.

title: 2¬† Motion, Speed, and Acceleration
text:
3.7 Projectiles
When you throw a ball from centerfield to home plate, the ball executes what looks like a parabollic trajectory. The ball goes forward while it probably rises for a while and then drops toward the ground. That‚Äôs two-dimensional motion and Galileo had the insipiration to figure out what was going on and how to do experiments to confirm his hypothesis that the up-and-down would follow the shape of a parabola.
His insight was that when motion is imparted to an object and the source of the motion is taken away (you throw the ball and it leaves your hand and is then in its own), that something stays with the ball. He called it ‚Äúimpeto‚Äù and we call it ‚Äúmomentum.‚Äù The ball acquires momentum.
And he realized that whatever impeto the ball acquires in the horizontal direction is preserved, but the moment the ball leaves your hand, it starts to head toward the Earth. In modern words, we‚Äôd say that once released, the ball has a horizontal momentum that stays constant and a vertical momentum that changes and points down. The two motions are in some sense overlaid or shared by the ball.

# #| out.width: ‚Äú700px‚Äù  
# #| column: screen
#| echo: false
knitr::include_graphics("screenshot_3677.png")







Figure¬†3.3: Throwing a ball. The vertical axis is the height above the ground and the horizontal axis is the range. The curve shows the trajectory of a thrown ball in the absence of any air resistance ‚Äì a perfect parabola. The intitial velocity is shown as the arrow at location 1. At each of the five points the overall velocity is broken into horizontal and vertical components.





In the figure you can see that the original velocity \(v_1\) points up and foward and I‚Äôve broken up this arrow (a vector) into it‚Äôs horizontal component which you can see at 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 is the same length. It‚Äôs ‚Äúimpeto‚Äù is constant. The vertical component changes at each point ‚Äì disappearing at the top ‚Äì¬†and then increasing down as the ball heads to Earth. Gravity wins.
For QS&BB we‚Äôll not need two dimensional kinematics.

4 Skinny Momentum and Force
This is the first of three outlines of some basic physics ideas so that I can refer to them in other posts. If you‚Äôd like more, including history and examples, then visit full textbook for a textbook-level presentation. If you only need the basic simple equations, they‚Äôre here. Units. Sorry. In QS&BB we won‚Äôt care about English versus metric units but for this motion review we‚Äôll sometimes have to convert. I‚Äôll do it for you but you can check me at places like unitjuggler‚Ä¶or often just Google.

title: 3¬† The Big Mo: Momentum and Force
text:
4.1 Just the facts:

4.1.1 some defintions

mass, \(m\), is the quantity of matter‚Ä¶but this concept changes over history and is somewhat circular. It has a couple of jobs to do.
Job 1: inertia is the reluctance of an object to move and the measure of interia is mass.
Job 2: impulse is related and sort of intuitive: push on something hard and it will go faster, push on something for a long time and it will go faster: \(F\Delta t\) is proportional to the change in velocity and the proportionality constant is \(m\)



4.1.2 impulse
\[
\begin{equation}
F\Delta t = m\Delta v
\end{equation}
\]


4.1.3 momentum
$$ \[\begin{align}
F\Delta t &= \Delta (mv) \nonumber \\
p &= mv \\
F\Delta t &= \Delta p \\

\end{align}\] $$


4.1.4 force
from the above: \[
\begin{align}
\text{rearranging impulse: }F &= \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} \\
\text{if the mass is constant } F &= ma
\end{align}
\]

title: 3¬† The Big Mo: Momentum and Force
text:
5.1 Isaac Newton‚Äôs important idea
To start something moving from rest? Apply a force. To speed up or slow down something already moving? Apply a force! To cause something to deviate from a straight line? Yes. Another force. To keep something moving at a constant speed? No (net) force required, thank you.
Here‚Äôs what he said:






Important



ü´µ Whenever there‚Äôs a change of velocity on any object, a force is at work: since acceleration is a change in velocity, forces are responsible for acceleration. Note: because velocity is technically a vector, then changing direction is also changing velocity.


One of the many ways that Newton got into the textbooks was to argue with Aristotle who insisted that all motion requires a pusher in physical contact: No, Newton said. Constant motion is free. It‚Äôs only accelerated motion that requires payment in the form of the action of a force.
Let‚Äôs start slowly and sneak up on this idea. Impulsively.

5.1.1 Impulse ‚Äì Every sport
In QS&BB we don‚Äôt need much depth, but we do need three important concepts‚Ä¶the ones that underpinned Newton‚Äôs system: force, mass, and momentum. Let‚Äôs move:
In the previous lesson we laid out the rules that govern an object‚Äôs motion.
Newton: To get something up to speed, you need to whack it or shove it ‚Äî either a sharp collision or a steady push increases the speed of an object. Push harder? More speed. Push longer? Again, more speed.
So let‚Äôs codify that everyday notion into a model of forces and motion. Let‚Äôs imagine a force, \(F\) that pushes during some time interval, \(\Delta t\). A whack means that \(\Delta t\) is small (like a golf club hitting a ball) while a steady shove (like a rugby scrum) means that the force is slowly applied so \(\Delta t\) is larger.
Here‚Äôs what we know from experience: applying a force (\(F\)) to something for a time interval (\(\Delta t\)) results in the speed increasing in proportion, (\(\Delta v\)). We have the beginnings of a model:
\[
\begin{equation}
F\Delta t \propto \Delta v. \label{eq:impulse1}
\end{equation}
\]
Increase \(F\), \(\Delta t\), or both on the left-hand side, and the speed goes up on the right-hand side. The quantity on the left side is called the Impulse. It‚Äôs the sports-quantity. Any game involving a ball involves impulse and exceptional athletes can control both the \(F\) and the \(\Delta t\). The quantity on the right implies that the speed changed and of course if the speed changed, then the object accelerated and/or it changed direction.
We need to refine the model. But first some units and language:

May the force be with you by so many different names We will use forces many times in QS&BB, which is a common quantity in our lives because of ‚Äúweight.‚Äù But if you‚Äôre from the United States, when you step on the bathroom scale it reports back to you your weight in the Imperial measurement system (or ‚Äúcustomary measures system‚Äù) as too many Pounds, lbs. In a minute, you‚Äôll see why that‚Äôs confusing when comparing to the rest of the world where the bathroom scale would report kilograms.  The unit of force in the International System of Units (SI), which includes the older ‚Äúmetric system‚Äù or MKS (Meter, Kilogram, Second) is the Newton, N. If you go to the gas station in Berlin, you‚Äôll fill your tires to a pressure measured in Pascals, which is Newtons per square meter. Of course up the street from me, our Michigan gas station reports pounds per square inch for my pressure.

We‚Äôll predominantly use the unit of Newton as the modern measure of a force ‚Äì like the rest of the civilized world. I‚Äôll not obsess with units and so I‚Äôm happy for you to rely on Mr.¬†Google in almost all instances.






Important



üîê Type this into your browser: ‚Äúconvert 10 pounds into newtons‚Äù and you‚Äôll be rewarded with the answer and a tool for all kinds of unit conversions. You‚Äôre welcome.




5.1.2 Inertia
Pressing forward (see what I did there?). Let‚Äôs think about pushing.
Suppose I apply a force of \(F=100\) pounds for 60 seconds to a Volkswagen and you apply a force of \(F=100\) pounds for 60 seconds to a little red wagon. We both begin our efforts at point A:

# #| out.width: ‚Äú700px‚Äù  
# #| column: screen
#| echo: false
knitr::include_graphics("./iwagon.png")







Figure¬†5.1: The same force applied to two red objects, of very different sizes





Will the resulting \(\Delta v\) at point B be the same for both vehicles?
Of course not. The little red wagon will gain more speed than the Volkswagen (regardless of its color). The VW is more reluctant to be accelerated than the wagon. So Equation \(\eqref{eq:impulse1}\) is not the whole story. What‚Äôs missing is just that reluctance that any object has to being accelerated, which has a name: inertia.
crumbs: 3¬† The Big Mo: Momentum and Force

title: 3¬† The Big Mo: Momentum and Force
text:
5.2 Newton‚Äôs Mass
Mass is a toughy and we‚Äôll see over and over how complicated it is ‚Äì to the current day. Here‚Äôs how he defined it in the Principia:
‚ÄúMass is the quantity of matter arising from its density and bulk conjointly.‚Äù
There you go. Useful? ‚Ä¶no?
You do perfectly well to accept the idea that mass is the quantitative measure of an object‚Äôs reluctance to be coaxed into changing its motion.
Here begins our love-hate relationship with mass. This much works:






Important



ü´µ Inertia is an object‚Äôs resistance to being accelerated and the measure of an object‚Äôs inertia is its mass.


This is the most profound and at the same time, the most mundane idea that Newton had!






Tip



üîê At the deep level of elementary particles, mass confuses us, perhaps in a different way from how it confuses engineering freshmen. We think that mass may actually not be an actual property of object, but rather a result of an object‚Äôs interaction with a spooky field that sprang into existence just after the birth of the Universe. Now, in the 21st century, we‚Äôve got a whole new set of neuroses about this subject, as understanding it occupies almost the entire Particle Physics community. So, Mass has been a problematic subject since its beginning in Newton‚Äôs hands.
crumbs: 3¬† The Big Mo: Momentum and Force

title: 3¬† The Big Mo: Momentum and Force
text:
5.3 The ‚ÄúQuantity of Motion‚Äù: Momentum
We just developed a sense that our hand-built, car-pushing formula, Equation \(\eqref{eq:impulse1}\) has to depend on speed and mass and so we‚Äôll just add it in on the right-hand side to get:
\[
\begin{equation}
F\Delta t = m\Delta v  \label{impulse2}
\end{equation}
\]
Being more explicit, when fleshed out impulse is
\[
\begin{equation}
F\Delta t = m(v - v_0) \label{fullimpulse}
\end{equation}
\]

There‚Äôs more to this story To be totally correct, the right hand side of this equation can be written as \(\Delta (mv)\) which recognizes that the mass might change instead of, or in addition to, the velocity changing. This is how a balloon jumps from your hand when you stop pinching the nozzle, or how a rocket is propelled by ejecting burned propellent out the back. In each case, the mass of the moving object changes and that results in a thrust. But we‚Äôll not encounter that in QS&BB.

This quantity on the right, \(mv\) is the definition of momentum. So the impulse is: $$ \[\begin{align}
F\Delta t &= \Delta (mv) \nonumber \\
F\Delta t &= \Delta p \label{momentumdef} \\

\end{align}\] $$
The athletic use of this is instinctive and learned‚Ä¶but with muscles and your neurosystem not paper and pencil:

# #| out.width: ‚Äú700px‚Äù  
# #| column: screen
#| echo: false
knitr::include_graphics("screenshot_3684.png")







Figure¬†5.2: The left-hand version where you want to change the velocity of a ball for example, in baseball, tennis, soccer, and golf‚Ä¶anything with a ball. The right-hand version where you have a fixed goal ‚Äì like stopping precisely ‚Äì fits football, gymnastics, and track and field.






So, repeat after me:

If there is no net force on an object

it‚Äôs motion doesn‚Äôt change
üëâ if its speed was zero‚Ä¶it stays zero
üëâ if its speed was 55 mph‚Ä¶it stays at 55 mph


Said another way, if you see the motion of any object changing‚Ä¶ then somewhere there is a force actiing (it might be invisible, like a magnetic field).
One quick change of Equation \(\eqref{momentumdef}\):
\[
\begin{align}
F\Delta t &= \Delta p \nonumber \\
F &= \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} \label{newtons2} \\
\text{since }&=\Delta p = \Delta (mv) \nonumber \\
\text{and if the mass is constant } &= \Delta p =m\Delta v \nonumber\\
F &= m \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \nonumber \\
\text{and since } &= \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = a \nonumber \\
F &= ma \label{newtons2b}
\end{align}
\] A couple of these are suitable for a T-shirt: Equation \(\eqref{newtons2}\) is ‚ÄúNewton‚Äôs Second law of Motion‚Äù in its most general physics-major form. Equation \(\eqref{newtons2b}\) is the T-shirt version for motion in which the mass of an object undergoing a push doesn‚Äôt change.

5.3.1 Newton‚Äôs 3 laws of motion
If there‚Äôs a second law, there must be a first one and there is‚Ä¶and a third one. Here they are for completeness:

An object with constant velociy will retain that constant velocity of zero or another value.
Best expressed as an equation as \(\eqref{newtons2}\).
For every force that object A applies to object B, an equal and opposite force will be appled by B to A.

The Third law is very useful for solving problems, but that‚Äôs not what we‚Äôre about in QS&BB.


5.3.2 Weight
There‚Äôs an important special case of Equation \(\eqref{newtons2b}\) which has to do with the earth and, well, everything that‚Äôs not nailed down. The earth attracts all objects with a force (which we‚Äôll talk about in a bit) that seems constant and has a partcular value of acceleration, that of gravity., We affectionately call it \(g\). So your weight is the force that the earth applies to you and so we simply have: \[
\begin{align}
F &= ma \text{ ...now modify for gravitational force}\nonumber \\
F &= W \text{ for the special force called "weight"} \nonumber \\
a &= g \text{ for the special acceleration of gravity} \nonumber\\
W &=mg \text{ which is weight on earth} \label{weight}
\end{align}
\] Two caveats:

We call this \(g\) ‚Äúlittle g‚Äù and it‚Äôs only got a specific value for the earth. There are different little g‚Äôs for other planets, moons, or stars.
The force of gravity is actually not constant ‚Äì stay tuned. But miles above tthe earth it‚Äôs still so close to \(g\) that we often pretend that it‚Äôs constant.

So little g is an important number:

In the american system, \(g = 32\) feet/second\(^2\) , 32 ft/s\(^2\)
For the rest of the world, \(g = 9.8\) meters/second\(^2\), 9.8 m/s$2
crumbs: 3¬† The Big Mo: Momentum and Force

title: 3¬† The Big Mo: Momentum and Force
text:
5.4 Circular Motion
Remember that if a velocity changes, then there‚Äôs an force acting as a cause and an acceleration is the result. Well, what about driving around a curve keeping your accelerator at 50 mph? This is the one time in QS&BB we‚Äôll care about the vector nature of velocity. A true (for a professional physicist or student) velocity has a magnitude (what your speedometer reads back) and a direction. So going 50 mph north is a different velocity than going 50 mph east. Same speed, different velocity.
Okay, what‚Äôs going on with you turning that corner where your direction changes but your speed doesn‚Äôt. From the formal definition, the velocity must change üëâ so there must be a force acting üëâ so there is an acceleration.
It might be easier to think of twirling something overhead. Suppose you tie a ball to a thin rope and get it rotating above your head in a horizontal plane, like our little guy in the margin.








Figure¬†5.3: Twirling a ball over your head in a horizontal plane.



You can feel a tug. That is, the ball seems to exert a force on your hand through the rope. But what‚Äôs really going on is that the ball wants to go forward (Newton‚Äôs first law) and you pull it back incrementally, bit by bit as it goes around. You‚Äôre supplying that force necessary to defeat its straight line motion.
This force-towards-the-center is called ‚Äúcentripetal force‚Äù ‚Äì you‚Äôve maybe heard of ‚Äúcentrifugal force‚Äù but that‚Äôs different and sometimes called ‚Äúficticious‚Äù which seems sort of insulting. But when you‚Äôre a passenger in a car that‚Äôs going around a curve, you feel a force that‚Äôs away from the center of the curve‚Ä¶that‚Äôs centifugal. But that‚Äôs just your body trying to obey that first law and go straight, while you‚Äôre in this car going, well, not straight. Where do you get the force that makes you follow the car? The door against your shoulder, the friction of the back of your lap on the seat, and hopefully your seatbelt. Absent those forces which pull you toward the center of the curve, you‚Äôd go flying.
The acceleration that you (or the ball) experience is toward the center of the circle (which we‚Äôll say has radius \(R\), following the direction of the force, and has its own formula and name of ‚Äúcentripetal acceleration‚Äù (\(a_c\)): \[
a_c=\frac{v^2}{R} \label{centripetala}
\] From Newton‚Äôs second law, there‚Äôs then a centripetal force. That tug you provide to the ball of mass \(m\) is: \[
\begin{align}
F_c &= m a_c \nonumber \\
F_c &=m \frac{v^2}{R} \label{centripetalf}
\end{align}
\]
